lines.text: I'm beginning to be very fond of you, Lieutenant. I think you're a very kind man.
Don't count on that, Miss Mitchell. Don't count on it.
[last lines]
Just think, Lieutenant, if you had investigated my niece's death, all this need never have happened.

[about Columbo's basset hound]
Is he all right?
Well, yes, ma'am. Do you see something wrong?
He seems to be scraping bottom.
Well, that's the way they were made.

[to his dog]
Okay. Now, don't go away. Stay.
[Dog runs off]
He's trained.
Amazing.
You know, I can remember the only new car my father ever bought. How proud he was. The way it smelled. Kind of like the inside of a Pullman car. It wasn't like this though, I'll tell you that.
My father never owned a car. Not until I bought him one. I was 20; I'd just sold my first book. Shall we compare poverty stories, Lieutenant?
Not in a Rolls Royce, ma'am.

[Referring to an old chair]
Can I sit in this?
Well, that's what it was made for 400 years ago.
Besides, I have work to do with Lieutenant Columbo.

[mocking]
'I have work to do with Lieutenant Columbo'. I wish Mrs. Columbo could hear that.
I can't tell you what a big help you've been.
"Big help to Lieutenant Columbo." Wish my publishers could hear you say that.
Abigail, you are the most exasperating woman I have ever met!
I accept all superlatives.
Is there murder in our civilized hearts? Obviously, there is in mine, and I'm well-paid.
My car's right here. It's French. Very rare.
[Abigail looks at Columbo's car, dust-covered, front grill manged, and with license plate askew]
Uh, yes. Oh, I can see why.

That must have been very hard losing someone you love like that. I've been very lucky. I've lost my parents, that's the way of the world. But to lose someone that young, that's like being cheated. That's very hard.
I'm beginning to be very fond of you, Lieutenant. I think you're a very kind man.
Don't count on that, Miss Mitchell. Don't count on it.
